report.title: Waterton
report.highlights: Currently Early Season Conditions exist in Waterton Park. Make sure to pack avalanche gear and prepare for snow as deeper pockets may be at threshold for avalanches. Regular avalanche bulletins will resume later in the fall.

summaries.content: No new avalanches observed, suspect most areas are below threshold for avalanche.
Up to 30cm of snow exists in the alpine, expect lee areas and drifts to be deeper.
For current weather forecast, please see Mountain Weather Forecast

report.title: Corner Brook-Gros Morne-Northern Peninsula
report.highlights: Factor avalanches into your trip plan and carry avalanche safety gear. Learn about early season conditions. Avalanche forecasts begin January 23.

summaries.content: More details can be found in the Mountain Weather Forecast.

report.title: Blue River-Clearwater-McBride-Premier-Quesnel-Sugarbowl-Bonnington-Grohman-Kootenay Pass-Norns-Rossland-South Okanagan-Ymir-Akamina-Flathead-Lizard-Clemina-Esplanade-Jordan-North Monashee-North Selkirk-Shuswap-East Kakwa-Kakwa-McGregor-Pine Pass-Renshaw-Robson-Tumbler-Boundary-Kitimat-Nass-Rupert-Seven Sisters-Shames-Stewart-Howson-Kispiox-Microwave-Sinclair-Ningunsaw-North Bulkley-South Bulkley-Telkwa-Crawford-Dogtooth-East Purcell-Moyie-St. Mary-West Purcell-Brandywine-Garibaldi-Homathko-Powell River-Spearhead-Tantalus-North Shore-Sasquatch-Sky Pilot-Tetrahedron-Birkenhead-Coquihalla-Duffey-Harrison-Fraser-Manning-Skagit-South Chilcotin-Stein-Taseko-Badshot-Battle-Central Selkirk-Goat-Gold-Kokanee-North Okanagan-Retallack-Valhalla-Whatshan-Bull-Crowsnest North-Crowsnest South-Elkford East-Elkford West-East Island-North Island-South Island-West Island-Tutshi-Wheaton-White Pass East-White Pass West-Haines Pass
report.highlights: Avalanches hazard may exist where there is snow. Pack a transceiver, shovel, and probe, and factor avalanches into your trip plan. Daily avalanche forecasts will begin November 26 at 4 PM.

summaries.content: More details can be found in the Mountain Weather Forecast.

report.title: Bow Valley-Highwood Pass-North 40-Spray - KLakes
report.highlights: There has been some windslabs avalanche activity noted in alpine terrain over the past week. The majority of these avalanches were sz 1.5 and running to upper treeline. Ice climbers think about overhead terrain and avalanche potential.

statements: Uncertainty is due to the limited number of field observations.

summaries.content: A few windslabs up to sz 2 were observed in flights throughout the region over this past week. These were mainly on N and E aspects.

Observations are still very limited.

Snow is accumulating at treeline and above. Weather stations are reporting 40cm of snow in alpine areas with amounts rapidly tapering at treeline and below.

A temperature crust from Nov 1st is down 10-15cm and being reported up to 2100m while a crust more basal in the snowpack is being reported into alpine areas on northern and eastern aspects.
More details can be found in the Mountain Weather Forecast.

problems.comment: Windslabs along ridgelines and in gullied terrain.

notifications.content: Areas of Kananaskis Country are intermittently closed for avalanche control using EXPLOSIVES. Closures will be indicated in headline below.

report.title: Chic-Chocs
report.highlights:
THE BULLETINS ARE DONE FOR THE SEASON – BACK ON DECEMBER 1ST, 2025.
Enjoy summer!

summaries.content: For the coming weeks, we invite you to consult the public weather resources recommended when preparing for a mountain outing and available here.

report.title: Banff-East Side 93N-Kootenay-Lake Louise-LLSA-Sunshine-West Side 93N-Field-Little Yoho
report.highlights:
Watch out for building hazard due to sluffing in steep gullies and new windslab development if the storm comes in as forecasted on Monday/Tuesday.

Monitor local weather conditions at Avalanche Canada's website.

summaries.content: No new avalanches observed or reported on Sunday but on Saturday, test firing of Mt Bosworth's remote avalanche control system (Gaz-Ex) produced two size 1.5 windslabs, both located on a South aspect at 2300m.

5–10 cm of storm snow has been redistributed into wind slabs in lee areas, especially in the alpine. Height of snow is 80-100cm in the alpine, 30–60 cm at treeline, and it tapers quickly below treeline. Early reports suggest that while the snowpack is generally thin, it supports the weight of a skier.

Temperatures are forecasted to cool overnight Sunday with Westerly winds decreasing slightly but staying strong throughout the day Monday. We expect 1-15 cm of new snow on Monday with higher amounts north of Lake Louise. Drier and calmer conditions are expected Tuesday.

Western Canada weather maps

problems.comment: There is enough snow in wind-loaded alpine and high treeline features to create avalanches, and human triggering is possible. While we expect these slides to be limited in size, getting avalanched in a shallow snowpack can easily result in an injury, so use caution in steep terrain.

terrainAndTravelAdvice: Watch for newly formed and reactive wind slabs as you transition into wind-affected terrain.
Use ridges or ribs to avoid areas of wind-loaded snow.

notifications.content: Area closures for avalanche control are in effect periodically from November to May. Click here for more information and maps.

report.title: Glacier
report.highlights:
Low snow coverage doesn't eliminate avalanche danger. A skier triggered a size 2.0 avalanche at Balu Pass yesterday.

Early season hazards abound. Expect to hit rocks, logs, and open creeks in your travels.

statements: Uncertainty is due to the limited number of field observations.

summaries.content:
A skier triggered a size 2.0 avalanche yesterday at Balu Pass in a wind stiffened area, and they went for a rocky ride. The avalanche was triggered from a thin area, and fractured ~30m above the rider caught. They were partially buried.

If there's enough to ride, there's enough to slide! Be sure to bring a transceiver, shovel and probe if you venture out.

There is ~120-140cms of snow on the ground in the Alpine, 80-120cm at treeline, and 20cm at the highway elevation.

A 6mm surface hoar layer is buried down ~30cm in all open areas treeline and above.

Glaciers have poor coverage with just enough snow to hide small crevasses.

The ridge breaks down, allowing the stormy Pacific low's to impact the interior again.

Tonight: Flurries, 12cm. Alpine low -2°C. Freezing level (FZL) 1700m. Ridge winds SW-45km/h. Weak temperature inversion.

Mon: Scattered flurries, 5cm. Alpine high -1°C. FZL 1900m. Winds SW 30-50km/h.

Tues: Isolated flurries, trace accumulation. Alp high -3°C, low -7°C. FZL 1600m. Wind SW-15 gusting 40km/h.

problems.comment:
Another 15cm storm is forecast for tonight into tomorrow, accompanied by strong SW'ly winds.

A layer of surface hoar exists down ~30cm. Although ground roughness breaks up slope connectivity early season, expect rider-triggered avalanches to be possible on smooth open slopes.

graphic.alt: North, Northeast, East, Southeast, south, Southwest, West, Northwest

terrainAndTravelAdvice: Surface hoar distribution is highly variable. Avoid generalizing your observations.
Approach lee and cross-loaded slopes with caution.

notifications.content: Large areas of Glacier National Park are CLOSED for avalanche control using EXPLOSIVES. Real Time Area Status - Winter Permit Information

report.title: Brazeau-Churchill-Cirrus-Wilson-Fryatt-Icefields-Maligne-Marmot-Miette Lake-Pyramid
report.highlights: Extreme winds are forecast from Sunday night until Monday evening. Wind speeds of up to 160 km/h are expected at both the Columbia Icefields and the Bald Hills. Expect widespread wind transport at treeline and above.

statements: Uncertainty is due to the track & intensity of the incoming weather system.

summaries.content: A few small loose dry avalanches were observed in the Alpine on Saturday.

Check here for how to navigate Early Season Conditions

Our field team ventured out to Hilda Ridge on Saturday and found generally supportive travel. Early season hazards exist with snow just covering rocks & trees.

Treeline has 30-55cm. The alpine is highly variable with either scoured back to rocks or loaded areas of over 100cm. Where the snow does exist there are windslabs. Alpine bowls & steep gullies are classic spots for early season avalanches.

Monday

Mainly cloudy with isolated flurries.

Precipitation: Up to 20 cm overnight

Alpine temperature: High -2 °C.

Extreme winds in the alpine out of the south west. Up to 160 km/hr in the alpine.

Tuesday

Mainly cloudy with isolated flurries.

Precipitation: Trace.

Alpine temperature: Low -7 °C, High -2 °C.

Extreme winds in the alpine out of the south west. Up to 160 km/hr in the alpine.

For updated forecast go to Jasper National Park Forecast.

problems.comment: There’s enough snow in the alpine to build up in lee features and steep gullies. While the problem may be small, the main concern is getting injured. A shallow snowpack and early season hazards can easily turn a minor slide into a bad situation.

terrainAndTravelAdvice: Be careful as you transition into wind-affected terrain.

notifications.content: Seasonal closures for caribou conservation in Jasper National Park are in effect from November to May. For more information, click here.
